@harshjain2 thanks for the contribution. Can you please format your code as per the Druid code style, see [here](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)

Part of the issue here is that the concept of "service" exists... but the concept of "capacity" or "feature" does not. So part of my proposal will be an experimental aspect which allows for "feature" discovery for features that rely on ID based stuff (hosting namespaced lookups, hosting segments, middle manager running tasks, etc). With the intent that the Coordinator make appropriate requests to all feature holders on what their configs should be.

The coordinator would then be the "what is the appropriate state?" holder, and ask the nodes with features to adjust their state accordingly.
Also you will need to update the documentation [here](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/docs/content/design/coordinator.md) with new changes
Please fill out the CLA [here](http://druid.io/community/cla.html) as well if you have not done so yet

@xvrl  rebase

With a little trick, current JDBCExtractionNamespace also supports above namespace like

```
"table": "(select A.a2 as key, C.c3 as value from A join B on A.a1 = B.b1 and B.b2 = C.c2 order by A.a2 limit 1000) sq",
"keyColumn": "key",
"valueColumn":"value"
```

I think it is not intuitive so it is better to support new parameter `query`.
However, it may require sanity check of the given query that it actually returns two columns (or three columns if tsColumn is used).
we should probably leave the old behavior as it is and mark it as deprecated so that any tools written around the existing api are not broken.
@fjy,  CLA Signed.

@himanshug I encountered this while working on a streaming, micro-batch indexer, however I see this as a general improvement of schema backwards compatibility. My indexer is built around incremental segment construction, with no window period. To accomplish this I make use of IndexMerger.merge(). I feel like ideally, one should not need to know the exact set of metrics in the indices that are being mergred, or at least should be able to use the latest schema version (which is what my indexer does). This PR allows for the scenario where your schema has grown and you are requesting to merge more metrics than are actually present. The case where there are more metrics present in the indices to merge than were requested is still an exception. 

If there is disagreement over whether requesting to merge more metrics than are present should be acceptable, this PR can easily be modified to detect this condition and throw a descriptive error, instead of the NullPointerException that currently occurs.
Hi @fjy yes, this is exactly what I want. So for now, I'll temporary use pivot instead. Hope this would be implemented soon. Thanks.

:+1: 

@navis please add documentation for select query that it is reversible

@binlijin I believe the use case you are describing is already supported by Druid. Can you double check this?

Try this query:

```
{
  "queryType": "topN",
  "dataSource": "dataSource",
  "dimension": "query",
  "metric": "pv",
  "threshold": 10,
  "granularity": "day",
  "postAggregations": [],
  "aggregations": [
    {
      "name": "pv",
      "fieldName": "pv",
      "type": "longSum"
    },
    {
      "name": "uv",
      "fieldName": "user_id_sketch",
      "type": "thetaSketch"
    }
  ],
  "intervals":["2015-01-01/2100-01-01"]
}
```

Issue your query with the context flag "doAggregateTopNMetricFirst": true

This should do the same thing as what your PR is describing this code doing. I think this context flag may have gone undocumented.

I think you may get the same performance, in which case, the optimization here may not be needed, and what is needed is to document that flag :)

It might also be useful to have a more automatic way of triggering this optimization rather than using the flag.

Can you be more specific?  Was this more than the "services/distribution" update indicated above?

@drcrallen keeping track of tasks which want to get a lock and this set is checked before Upgrading a lock if there are higher priority tasks then Upgrade request fails. This way there is no need to introduce sleeps between downgrade and upgrade requests in Restore, Archive, Move and Kill task. I think this should address your concern. Added unit test for the same.

@navis having a hive storage adapter would be good but it appears you are thinking of fetching data from historical nodes (and realtime nodes). IMO it will be much more scalable to read segments from hdfs directly.
I wrote a hadoop InputFormat ( a simple wrapper around druid's DatasourceInputFormat) and a Pig loader that works that way (planning to move InputFormat to druid core) , see
@drcrallen I wonder if this PR overlaps #2242, where I've been working on separating internal/external announcement and Druid service discovery.

@guobingkun partly. which is why I put it up as quickly as I could. I was using the approach from this PR in the metadata propagation for QTL, but thought it might be able to be used for stuff at a wider capacity.

There are separate parts of your PR compared to this one. It would be a good idea for you, myself, and @xvrl to sync up to come up with a unified approach and distinction of responsibilities for the micro-components in the PRs.

Logging comments need addressed though or else the exceptions will get eaten up by the logging framework.
